column3: the General Court of Massachusetts passed "An act for erecting part of the town of Newbury into a new town by the name of Newburyport." The act begins:Whereas the town of Newbury is very large
column4: and the inhabitants of that part of it who dwell by the water-side there
column5: as it is commonly called
column6: are mostly merchants
column7: traders and artificers
column8: and the inhabitants of the other parts of the town are chiefly husbandmen; by means whereof many difficulties and disputes have arisen in managing their public affairs – Be it enacted ... That that part of the said town of Newbury ... be and hereby are constituted and made a separate and distinct town ....

column1: The act was approved by Governor Francis Bernard on February 4
column2: 1764. The new town was the smallest in Massachusetts
column3: covering an area of 647 acres (2.62 km2)
column4: and had a population of 2
column5: 800 living in 357 homes. There were three shipyards
column6: no bridges
column7: and several ferries
column8: one of which at the foot of Greenleaf Lane

column13: and Boston.The town prospered and became a city in 1851. Situated near the mouth of the Merrimack River
column16: with an industry in silverware manufacture. In 1792
column17: a bridge was built two miles above the town where the river contained an island. Merrimack Arms and Brown Manufacturing Company made Southerner Derringer pistols in their Newburyport factory from 1867 to 1873. The captains of old Newburyport (as elsewhere in Massachusetts) had participated vigorously in the triangular trade
column18: importing West Indian molasses and exporting rum made from it. The distilleries were located around Market Square near the waterfront. Caldwell's Old Newburyport rum was manufactured locally until well into the 19th century.

column1: The Atlantic slave trade supported much of Newburyport's early growth and prosperity
column2: with ships built in Newburyport and sold by Newburyport merchants used in the transportation of enslaved people from Africa
column3: and Newburyport rum distilleries being a major destination of resources extracted by slave labor in the Caribbean. Racial segregation in what is today called Newburyport was practiced as early as 1683
column4: when the selectmen of Newbury banished a free African woman
column5: Juniper
column6: from the town. In 1755
column7: as many as fifty enslaved African and Native American people lived in present-day Newburyport. An enslaved girl was advertised for sale in Newburyport as late as 1774
column8: well after the incorporation of Newburyport as a distinct municipality from Newbury. Just the year prior
column11: had successfully sued Newburyport resident Richard Greenleaf for his freedom.Newburyport prior to the Civil War had always been divided over slavery. While many of its leading citizens profited from and defended slavery
column12: it also had been a frequent topic of pulpit rhetoric. After the Revolutionary War
column14: Newburyport included. Several citizens are recognized by the National Park Service for their contributions to the Underground Railroad. The abolitionist movement reached a peak with the activities of William Lloyd Garrison
column15: who was born in Newburyport and helped develop an anti-slavery climate. In 1841
column16: Garrison was imprisoned on charges of libel for accusing Newburyport shipowner Francis Todd and captain Nicholas Brown of transporting 44 African captives in chains. His statue stands in Brown Square
column17: which was the scene of abolitionist meetings.

column1: Newburyport once had a fishing fleet that operated from Georges Bank to the mouth of the Merrimack River. It was a center for privateering during the Revolutionary War and War of 1812. Beginning about 1832
column2: it added numerous ships to the whaling fleet. Later
column3: clipper ships were built there. Today
column4: the city gives little hint of its former maritime importance. Notably missing are the docks
column5: which are shown on earlier maps extending into the channel of the Merrimack River
column6: and the shipyards
column7: where the waterfront parking lot is currently located.

column2: the well-known and influential English preacher who helped inspire the First Great Awakening in America

column4: brought into existence Old South Church
column5: where he was buried after his death in 1770.

in the 1950s and 1960s Newburyport's center fell into disrepair because of several factors
column3: most notably strip malls taking away from local business and increased use of the automobile. At this time
column4: construction of major highways brought larger cities such as Lawrence and Lowell into shopping range. Consequently
column5: by 1970 Newburyport's historic downtown section was scheduled to be razed prior to reconstruction with federal money. Ideas to rebuild the city's downtown were numerous
column6: ranging from hotels and new stores to
column7: ironically
column9: with few buildings left for historical reasons. At the last moment
column11: the city changed its mind and signed a federal grant that allowed it to keep most of its historic architecture. Renovation and restorations began during the early 1970s
column12: and continued throughout most of the decade
column14: and culminating with creation of a pedestrian mall along Inn Street.  Newburyport is often cited as an example by preservationists of how to maintain a city's architecture and heritage
column15: while still having it remain functional and liveable.

column1: The city is part of Massachusetts' North Shore; Newburyport was laid out on the elevated south bank of the Merrimack River between the river and Newbury marshes. The shipyards
column2: now boatyards (and still vigorously active)
column3: extended along the bank at the edge of the river. They were connected by Merrimac Street
column4: which ends upriver where the bank merges into bluffs covered with pine forest. Colonial residences extend up the bank from Merrimac Street to High Street running parallel to it near the top of the ridge. The homes of the seafaring entrepreneurs line High Street. Many feature widow's walks
column5: structures on the roof where the residents could watch for the return of sailing vessels. Nearly every home maintains a splendid flower garden
column6: most dating to colonial times. Various cross streets
column7: such as State Street
column9: connect Merrimac Street and High Street. The top of the ridge proved an ideal location for later institutions
column10: such as Newburyport High School and nearby Anna Jaques Hospital. The ridge drops more sharply to the marsh on the other side. Along its margin a third parallel street developed

column1: The river bank gradually descends to marshes at Joppa Flats beyond downtown Newburyport. The Plum Island Turnpike was pushed out over the marsh on a causeway to a narrow part of the Plum Island River just to the south of where it connects to the mouth of the Merrimack. A drawbridge was built there
column2: the only access to the island by road. On the Newburyport side a small airport
column3: Plum Island Airport
column4: was built at the edge of the marsh. The portion of Plum Island that is in the city has no direct access to the rest of the city; similarly
column5: there is no access between the mainland and Woodbridge Island or Seal Island
column6: west of Plum Island (the latter being shared between Newburyport and Newbury). Several parks and beaches dot the city
column7: including Plum Island Point Beach
column13: Moseley Pines Park and Atkinson Common and March's Hill Park.  Newburyport Forest is located in the southwest corner of the city
column14: and Maudslay State Park lies along the northwest part of the city
column15: along the banks of the Merrimack.

column1: Newburyport is part of the Massachusetts Senate's 1st Essex district.
Interstate 95 passes through the western side of town
column2: with one exit at Route 113.  Route 113 itself has its eastern terminus at U.S. Route 1 and Massachusetts Route 1A
column3: with Route 1A continuing along the same right of way as 113 towards Newbury.  Route 1 and 1A cross the river along the Newburyport Turnpike Bridge; it had originally followed State Street and ended at Merrimac and Water streets before crossing the river via ferry to Salisbury.  The Turnpike Bridge is the easternmost crossing of the Merrimack; upstream the river is crossed by the Newburyport Railroad Bridge (just west of the Turnpike Bridge)
column4: the Chain Bridge
column5: one of the oldest bridges along the river
column6: and the Whittier Memorial Bridge
column7: which brings Interstate 95 to Amesbury.

column1: The Merrimack Valley Regional Transit Authority provides regular bus service between the city and Haverhill
column2: which includes access to the commuter rail station in Newburyport. The bus costs $1.25 for adults paying cash and $1 for adults paying with CharlieCard. C&J and Coach Company
column3: privately operated coach carriers
column4: operate commuter bus services between Newburyport and Boston. Newburyport is the northern terminus of the Newburyport/Rockport Line of the MBTA Commuter Rail system
column5: providing access through several North Shore cities to Boston's North Station.Plum Island Airport is a privately owned general aviation airport located within the city limits. It is open to the public and managed by Plum Island Aerodrome
column6: Inc.
column7: a not-for-profit organization. The nearest scheduled commercial air service can be found at Boston's Logan International Airport
column9: Portsmouth's Pease International Tradeport or Manchester's Manchester-Boston Regional Airport.

column1: The current site of Newburyport High School was purchased from Harvard University early in the 20th century. Newburyport High School is one of the oldest public high schools in the United States.

column4: Inc.
column5: is the annual festival celebrating the natives coming home to Newburyport. The event was initiated in 1957 by native Newburyporter George Cashman
column6: who sought to stimulate the economy and lift the spirit of the citizens.

column1: It lasts one week. The first Sunday of the festival
column2: known as "Olde Fashioned Sunday"
column3: is celebrated at the Bartlet Mall in Newburyport
column4: and features many activities
column5: including an art show
column6: an appearance by the city's oldest fire engine
column7: the "Neptune #8"
column8: and the participation of many local businesses. There is also an antique car parade. Each Yankee Homecoming features a grand marshal and numerous street vendors.

column1: The festival includes eight days and over 200 events. There are concerts every night at Market Landing Park.  Other popular events include the Newburyport Lions' 10-mile (16 km) and 5-kilometer road races
column2: which run through the city's downtown streets and neighborhoods. There is also a 45-minute fireworks show on Saturday night
column3: which is followed the concluding Sunday by the famous Yankee Homecoming parade.

column2: Newburyport's "Yankee Homecoming" is the second-oldest homecoming festival in the United States. Many charities raise their funds during this time.

column1: This was held Friday evenings in Waterfront Park in downtown Newburyport
column2: these free concerts were intended for all ages. The concerts were presented by the Newburyport Chamber of Commerce and the Waterfront Trust and were sponsored by a local insurance agency

column1: Held during the last weekend of April
column2: the Newburyport Literary Festival was started in 2006 as a new effort by the city to increase interest in reading and literary arts. Many local authors are invited to sign and chat about their book
column3: and schoolchildren create projects to show to an author who visits their school. Among the authors who regularly visit are Andre Dubus III
column4: Tess Gerritsen and Rhina Espaillat.

column2: the town has cultivated a significant tourist population. The quaint downtown shopping center includes businesses that appeal to all ages. Local businesses and restaurants surround Market Square and along State Street. During festivals throughout the year
column3: visitors are invited to enjoy concerts
column4: food
column5: and entertainment. An old mill building on Liberty Street is home to other small businesses and a local farmers' market during both the summer and winter seasons. The historic area has a charming feel and upbeat atmosphere.

column1: High Street is a remarkable street of fine old Federal-style houses
column2: linking the Atkinson Common (1893–1894) with the Bartlett Mall
column3: site of the Charles Bulfinch-designed Essex County Superior Courthouse (1805). Laid out in 1801
column4: the Bartlett Mall was redesigned in the 1880s by noted Boston landscape architect Charles Eliot
column5: with later improvements by Arthur Shurcliff.

column1: First Presbyterian Church dates from 1756. The clock tower bell was cast by Paul Revere. One of the most famous individuals in 18th-century America
column2: evangelist George Whitefield
column3: before dying in Newburyport in 1770
column4: asked that his remains be buried under the pulpit of the "Old South" church
column5: and they are there to this day.

column3: part of the Cthulhu Mythos. The narrative also cameos the actual Newburyport in the first chapter. It is where the protagonist sets out from on his journey to Innsmouth.
